caption: Table 1: Training data for deep face recognition. The cleaned WebFace42M is the largest public training set in terms of both # identities and # images.
Table 2: The # identities and # images statistics during different stages.

Table 3: The statistics of our test set. -means corresponding statistics or 
comparisons are omitted.

Table 4: Speed and performance comparison of distributed training. Arc-
Face using ResNet-100 is adopted. B, G and M refer to batch size per GPU, 
# GPUs per machine, and # machines. X and W mean feature and center, 
and numbers in bracket are the GPU memory usage (MB). Performance is 
reported on IJB-C (TAR@FAR=1e-4).

Table 5: Performance (%) of different training data. ResNet-100 backbone 
without flip test is adopted. Pairs refers to average accuracy on

Table 6: Performance of ArcFace models trained with ResNet-14 on dif-
ferent portions of WebFace42M. TAR@FAR=1e-4 on IJB-C is reported.

caption:
Table 7: Comparisons of CAST and other data cleaning pipelines. ResNet-
100 using the ArcFace loss is adopted here. For our WebFace, different 
iterations are compared. CAST-1 means the first-round iteration.

Table 8: Comparisons of different intra-class cleaning methods for MS1M. 
ResNet-100 using the ArcFace loss is adopted here.

Table 9: Settings and inference time of baselines. Loose cropped test im-
ages are resized to 224 ? 224 for joint detection and alignment. M-0.25 
and R-50 refer to RetinaFace using MobileNet-0.25 (23ms) and ResNet-50 
(272ms) as the backbones. FLOPs and Params mean computational com-
plexity and parameter number of recognition module, respectively. Time 
refers to the duration of the whole system.

Table 10: Results on NIST-FRVT. Our Arcface model using ResNet-200 
is trained on WebFace42M. FNMR at corresponding FMR is reported.
